cheatsheet:
1. <note1>
  <description>When a total quantity is divided into parts, express each part as a fraction of the total. If one part is known, its fraction is 1 minus the sum of the other known fractions. This ensures all parts sum to 1.</description>
  <example>Suppose three segments sum to 100 units. If segment A is 20 units and segment B is 30 units, then segment C = 100 – (20 + 30) = 50 units, since A and B together occupy 50% of the total.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Translate comparative statements into multiplication or division of a base quantity. If one quantity is k times another, multiply the base by k; if it is a fraction of the base, multiply by that fraction.</description>
  <example>Given a base length L, a second length that is 4 times L is 4·L, and a third length that is half of L is 0.5·L. These expressions can then be used in further calculations.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the equation Total = Sum of parts to solve for an unknown part. Rearrange the equation by subtracting known parts from the total to isolate the unknown.</description>
  <example>If the total distance is D and two parts are P₁ and P₂, then the third part P₃ = D – (P₁ + P₂). For instance, if D = 100 and P₁ + P₂ = 60, then P₃ = 40.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check consistency by verifying that all parts sum to the original total and that each part’s value is nonnegative. This guards against arithmetic or sign errors.</description>
  <example>After finding parts A = 20, B = 30, and C = 50, confirm 20 + 30 + 50 = 100. Also ensure each part ≥ 0. If any check fails, re-examine the setup.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>When dealing with fractional or decimal parts, convert them to a common denominator or decimal form before summing. This prevents rounding errors and simplifies arithmetic.</description>
  <example>To add 1/3, 1/4, and 1/6, convert to twelfths: 4/12 + 3/12 + 2/12 = 9/12 = 3/4. Then subtract from 1 to find the remaining fraction.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert a weekly usage rate into a monthly rate by multiplying by the number of weeks in a month (typically 4). This scales the per-week quantity to the per-month quantity.</description>
  <example>For a usage rate of U items per week, multiply by 4 to get 4·U items per month.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a single unit has a known capacity, multiply that capacity by the total number of units to find the overall capacity. This applies to any scenario where you have multiple identical containers or items.</description>
  <example>If each container holds C units and there are N containers, the total capacity is N·C.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the distributive property to simplify expressions: a·(b + c) = a·b + a·c. This can help break down complex multiplications into simpler parts.</description>
  <example>To compute 5·(3 + 7), rewrite as 5·3 + 5·7 = 15 + 35 = 50.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check for unit consistency: ensure all quantities are in the same units before adding or multiplying. Convert units if necessary to avoid errors.</description>
  <example>If one rate is in “items per week” and another in “items per day,” convert one to match the other before combining them.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Perform a sanity check by estimating the result with rounded numbers. This quick check helps catch arithmetic or unit conversion mistakes.</description>
  <example>For 4·30, estimate 4·30 ≈ 4·30 = 120, then verify the exact calculation is 120.</example>
</note5>

Use the complement rule: if a fraction p of items have a property, then (1–p) do not. This lets you convert between “with” and “without” counts directly.
Example: If 60% of students have a book, then 40% do not. If 12 students do not have a book, the total is 12 ÷ 0.40 = 30 students.
Avoid mixing percentages and decimals without converting them first.

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the periodicity of a repeating event to determine when the next occurrence happens. If an event recurs every P units, then the next occurrence after a given time T is at T + P.</description>
  <example>Suppose a festival happens every 12 days. If it occurred on day 5, the next one will be on day 5 + 12 = 17.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Translate age relationships into algebraic equations. If Person A is k times as old as Person B at a certain time, set A = k·B. This converts verbal age statements into solvable equations.</description>
  <example>“At a certain moment, Person A is twice as old as Person B.” If B’s age is x, then A’s age is 2x.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Model the time difference between two observations by subtracting the earlier time from the later time. If the first event is at time T₁ and the second at T₂, then the interval is T₂ – T₁.</description>
  <example>If a meeting is scheduled for 10:00 and another for 14:00, the time between them is 14:00 – 10:00 = 4 hours.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the periodicity of the event to relate the time difference to the event’s period. If the event repeats every P, then the time difference between two occurrences must be a multiple of P.</description>
  <example>If a train runs every 30 minutes, then the time between two consecutive departures is 30 minutes, which is exactly one period.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Combine the time difference equation with the periodicity condition to form a linear equation. Solve for the unknown time or age by isolating the variable.</description>
  <example>Suppose the time between two events is T₂ – T₁ = m·P, and you know T₁ and P. Then T₂ = T₁ + m·P, and you can solve for m or T₂ as needed.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Model linear growth by adding a constant each period: if you start with S and add A each period, after n periods you have S + n·A. This applies whenever a quantity increases by the same amount every time step.</description>
  <example>Starting with 50 items and adding 3 each period, after 4 periods you have 50 + 4·3 = 50 + 12 = 62 items.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Model linear decay by subtracting a constant each period: if you start with S and remove D each period, after n periods you have S – n·D. Use this when a quantity decreases by the same amount every time step.</description>
  <example>Starting with 80 units and removing 2 each period, after 5 periods you have 80 – 5·2 = 80 – 10 = 70 units.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Combine growth and decay in one step: net change per period is (A – D). After n periods, total change is n·(A – D). This simplifies multi-step processes with both additions and subtractions.</description>
  <example>If you add 4 and remove 1 each period, net change is 3 per period. After 6 periods, total change is 6·3 = 18, so you end up 18 more than you started.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Convert a percentage loss into a multiplier: a p% loss means you retain (100 – p)% of the quantity. Multiply the current amount by (1 – p/100) to apply the loss.</description>
  <example>If 20% of a stock of 100 items perish, you retain 80%: 100·(1 – 0.20) = 100·0.80 = 80 items remain.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check for negative or zero results: if net change per period is negative, the quantity may drop below zero. In such cases, interpret the result as zero or adjust the model to prevent invalid values.</description>
  <example>If you remove 5 each period but start with only 3, after 1 period you have 3 – 5 = –2, which is invalid. You should interpret this as 0 items remaining.</example>
</note5>

accumulate
<note1>
  <description>When quantities are added sequentially, sum them directly. This works because addition is associative and commutative, so the order of addition does not affect the total.</description>
  <example>Suppose you collect a₁ items on day 1, a₂ on day 2, and a₃ on day 3. The total is a₁ + a₂ + a₃.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Use multiplication to scale a known quantity by a factor. If you know a base amount a and it is scaled by a factor k, the new amount is k·a.</description>
  <example>If you have a₁ items and you double that amount, the new count is 2·a₁.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Introduce variables for each unknown quantity to set up an equation. Assign a variable to each distinct amount, then express relationships between them.</description>
  <example>Let x be the amount on day 1, y on day 2, and z on day 3. If z is three times x, write z = 3·x.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Combine like terms to simplify the sum of variables. If multiple variables represent the same type of quantity, add their coefficients to get a single term.</description>
  <example>Given x + x + 3x, combine to get 5x, since 1x + 1x + 3x = 5x.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Always verify your result by substituting back into the original conditions. This ensures no arithmetic or logical errors were made.</description>
  <example>After finding the total T = 5x, check that T matches the sum of the individual amounts a₁, a₂, and a₃ as defined.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>Identify and assign a variable to each unknown duration. Use a single variable for the base duration and express all other durations as multiples or fractions of that variable.</description>
  <example>Let x be the duration of the first activity. If the second activity lasts twice as long, represent it as 2x. This keeps all durations in terms of x for easy manipulation.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Translate comparative phrases into algebraic expressions: “three times” becomes 3·x, “half as long” becomes ½·x, and “twice as long” becomes 2·x. This ensures consistency in unit representation.</description>
  <example>For an activity that is three times the first, write 3x. For one that is half the first, write ½x. This avoids mixing different units or misinterpretation.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>Sum all algebraic expressions to form a single equation for the total duration. Combine like terms by adding coefficients of the same variable.</description>
  <example>Given durations x, 3x, ½x, ½·(3x), and 2x, sum them: x + 3x + ½x + 1.5x + 2x = (1+3+0.5+1.5+2)x = 8x.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>Perform arithmetic on coefficients to simplify the total expression. Combine fractions and integers to get a single coefficient for the variable.</description>
  <example>Combine 1 + 3 + 0.5 + 1.5 + 2 = 8. Thus the total duration is 8x, where x is the base duration.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>Interpret the simplified expression in context. The coefficient of the variable represents the total number of base units (e.g., hours) for the entire schedule.</description>
  <example>If x = 1 hour, then 8x = 8 hours. This directly gives the total time spent on all activities.</example>
</note6>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “half” of another, multiply the other quantity by 1/2. For “triple,” multiply by 3. This converts verbal relationships into algebraic expressions.</description>
  <example>Suppose A has X items. If B has half as many, then B = (1/2)·X. If C has triple as many, then C = 3·X.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Translate each verbal statement into an equation: “half of X” → (1/2)X, “triple of Y” → 3Y. This ensures you capture the exact relationship before combining.</description>
  <example>“D has twice as many as E” becomes D = 2·E. “F has one-third as many as G” becomes F = (1/3)·G.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>After forming individual expressions, sum them to get the total. For example, if B = (1/2)X and C = 3Y, then total = B + C = (1/2)X + 3Y.</description>
  <example>Given P = 2·M and Q = 5·N, the combined total is P + Q = 2M + 5N.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check units and consistency: ensure all terms share the same unit (e.g., all counts of paint tubes). Mixing units (like counts vs. volumes) leads to errors.</description>
  <example>If one term is “3 boxes” and another is “5 liters,” you cannot add them directly. Convert both to the same unit before summing.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify by substitution: plug the original values into your expressions and recompute. This guards against algebraic or arithmetic mistakes.</description>
  <example>Given X = 10 and Y = 4, compute B = (1/2)·10 = 5 and C = 3·4 = 12, then check total = 5 + 12 = 17 matches your final result.</example>
</note5>

Use the XML-ish format:
  <note1><description>...</description><example>...</example></note1>
  <note2>...</note2>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a service is billed at a fixed rate per unit of time, multiply the rate by the duration to get the total cost. This applies to any hourly or per-minute fee.</description>
  <example>For a service costing $r per hour and lasting h hours, the cost is r × h. For instance, if r = $5 and h = 2, the cost is 5 × 2 = $10.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a fee is charged per item, multiply the unit price by the quantity purchased. This holds for any discrete item count.</description>
  <example>If each item costs p and you buy q items, the total is p × q. For example, if p = $2 and q = 5, the total is 2 × 5 = $10.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>When a fee is a fixed amount regardless of usage, include it directly in the total. This is common for mandatory fees or minimum service charges.</description>
  <example>If there is a fixed fee f, add f to the sum of all other costs. For instance, if f = $10 and other costs total $20, the final cost is 10 + 20 = $30.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>When a service duration is given in mixed units (e.g., hours and minutes), convert all to the same unit before multiplying by the rate. Use conversion factors (e.g., 1 hour = 60 minutes).</description>
  <example>If a service lasts h hours and m minutes at rate r per hour, compute total time as (h + m/60) hours, then cost = r × (h + m/60). For example, if h = 1, m = 30, and r = $10, total time = 1.5 hours, cost = 10 × 1.5 = $15.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always sum all individual costs to get the final total. This ensures no fee is omitted and all charges are accounted for.</description>
  <example>Given costs c₁, c₂, c₃, …, the total is c₁ + c₂ + c₃ + … . For instance, if c₁ = $10, c₂ = $20, c₃ = $30, the total is 10 + 20 + 30 = $60.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute total cost by multiplying unit price by quantity for each item, then summing. This applies whenever you need the combined cost of multiple items with different prices.</description>
  <example>For 4 items at $3 each and 2 items at $5 each, total cost = 4×3 + 2×5 = 12 + 10 = 22.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Find the difference between two totals by subtracting the smaller total from the larger. This gives the price difference or gap between two purchase scenarios.</description>
  <example>If one scenario costs 22 and another costs 15, the difference = 22 − 15 = 7.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the distributive property to simplify expressions like a·x + b·y. Factor common terms or combine like terms to reduce arithmetic steps.</description>
  <example>Instead of 3×4 + 3×2, factor 3(4 + 2) = 3×6 = 18, which is faster than adding then multiplying.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for unit consistency: ensure all prices and quantities use the same unit (e.g., dollars per item, items per batch). Mismatched units lead to incorrect totals.</description>
  <example>If one price is in cents and another in dollars, convert both to cents (or dollars) before summing to avoid errors.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify by reverse calculation: add the computed totals and then subtract one from the other to confirm the difference. This catches arithmetic mistakes.</description>
  <example>After finding totals 22 and 15, compute 22 − 15 = 7, then re-add 15 + 7 = 22 to ensure consistency.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the ceiling function to determine the minimum number of whole packages needed when each package contains a fixed quantity. The formula is: number_of_packages = ceil(total_items / items_per_package). This ensures you account for any leftover items that require an additional package.</description>
  <example>Suppose you need 17 items and each package holds 5. Compute ceil(17/5) = ceil(3.4) = 4 packages. Thus, you must purchase 4 packages to cover all 17 items.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Apply the unit-rate method to find the total cost by multiplying the number of packages by the cost per package. This linear scaling works whenever the cost is directly proportional to the quantity purchased.</description>
  <example>If each package costs $3.00 and you need 4 packages, then total cost = 4 × $3.00 = $12.00.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Verify your result by checking that the total items from the computed packages meet or exceed the requirement. This check prevents underestimating the number of packages and ensures you have enough items.</description>
  <example>With 4 packages of 5 items each, you get 4 × 5 = 20 items, which is more than the required 17. This confirms the ceiling calculation was correct.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Watch out for rounding down when using floor division, as it can lead to insufficient items. Always use the ceiling function to avoid undercounting.</description>
  <example>If you compute 17/5 = 3.4 and round down to 3, you get 3 × 5 = 15 items, which is 2 short. Using ceil(17/5) = 4 avoids this shortfall.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Perform a sanity check by comparing the computed total cost to the cost of purchasing just enough items without packages. This helps catch any overestimation or underestimation in the package count.</description>
  <example>If items cost $0.50 each and you need 17, the direct cost is 17 × $0.50 = $8.50. If packages cost $3.00 each and you need 4, the cost is $12.00. Since $12.00 is higher, you confirm that buying in packages is more expensive in this case.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>Convert total units into required resource quantity by multiplying the unit rate (resource per unit) by the total units. This gives the exact amount of resource needed.</description>
  <example>For a recipe requiring 2 units of ingredient per batch and 10 batches, multiply 2 × 10 = 20 units of ingredient needed.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Apply a percentage discount by multiplying the original price by (1 – discount rate). This yields the discounted unit price.</description>
  <example>If an item costs $10 and there is a 25% discount, compute 10 × (1 – 0.25) = $7.50 as the sale price.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Compute total cost by multiplying the discounted unit price by the total quantity purchased. This gives the final expense.</description>
  <example>With a discounted price of $7.50 per unit and 5 units bought, total cost = 7.50 × 5 = $37.50.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Use the unitary method: find the cost per single unit, then scale up to the desired quantity. This simplifies multi-step calculations.</description>
  <example>If 3 units cost $15, then one unit costs 15 ÷ 3 = $5. For 8 units, cost = 5 × 8 = $40.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Always verify that the discount applies per unit or per batch and that the total quantity aligns with the offer. Misreading the discount term can lead to errors.</description>
  <example>A “buy 1 get 1 free” offer on 2-unit packs means you pay for one pack and get one free, so total cost = price of one pack, not two.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a known quantity is a fraction of an unknown total, set up the equation “known = (fraction) × total.” This directly relates the given part to the whole.</description>
  <example>Suppose a student scored 80 points, which is 4/5 of the maximum. Write 80 = (4/5) × total to find the total possible points.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>To solve for the unknown total, divide both sides of the equation by the fraction. This isolates the total variable.</description>
  <example>From 80 = (4/5) × total, divide by 4/5: total = 80 ÷ (4/5) = 80 × (5/4) = 100.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Always simplify the fraction before multiplying or dividing. Simplifying reduces arithmetic complexity and minimizes errors.</description>
  <example>For 80 ÷ (4/5), rewrite as 80 × (5/4). Simplify 80/4 = 20 first, then multiply: 20 × 5 = 100.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check your result by substituting back into the original fraction. Ensure the computed total, when multiplied by the fraction, returns the known quantity.</description>
  <example>With total = 100 and fraction = 4/5, compute (4/5) × 100 = 80, which matches the given known quantity.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Be cautious of misreading “of” as multiplication versus addition. In fraction problems, “of” always indicates multiplication by the fraction.</description>
  <example>Do not write “known + fraction = total”; instead, use known = (fraction) × total to avoid incorrect setups.</example>
</note1>

breakdown
<note1>
  <description>When a base group of size N each contributes a fixed number of additional items (e.g., friends), the total from that group is N × (1 + k), where k is the number of extra items per member. This accounts for the original member plus k additional items.</description>
  <example>Suppose 50 people each bring 3 extra guests. The total from that group is 50 × (1 + 3) = 200 items.</example>
</note2>
  <description>For a second group of size M that each brings a different fixed number of items (e.g., partners), the total is M × (1 + p), where p is the number of extra items per member. This handles a distinct contribution pattern.</description>
  <example>If 12 people each bring 1 partner, the total from that group is 12 × (1 + 1) = 24 items.</example>
</note3>
  <description>When multiple groups contribute independently, sum their totals to get the grand total. This additive principle applies whenever contributions do not overlap or interact.</description>
  <example>Group A contributes 200 items and Group B contributes 24 items; the overall total is 200 + 24 = 224 items.</example>
</note4>
  <description>Always verify that you’ve accounted for each member exactly once and that you’ve included all specified extra items. A common pitfall is double-counting or omitting a group.</description>
  <example>After computing 200 + 24, check that you didn’t accidentally add the same person twice or forget the partner group entirely.</example>
</note5>
  <description>Use a simple check by estimating the total: if the sum of individual group contributions is far from the expected range, re-examine the multiplication or addition steps.</description>
  <example>If you expect around 200 items but your calculation gives 224, ensure you multiplied correctly and that you included both groups.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert all quantities to a single unit before combining. Use multiplication or division to change dozens, dozens of dozens, or other units into the base unit (e.g., individual items).</description>
  <example>Suppose you have 3 dozen items and 7 individual items. Convert 3 dozen to 3×12=36 items, then add 7 to get 43 items in total.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute total resources by summing all contributions. This ensures you account for every available resource before any further calculations.</description>
  <example>If you have 2 boxes of 10 tokens and 5 loose tokens, sum 2×10+5=25 tokens in total.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the division algorithm to find how many full groups of size k can be formed from a total of N items: quotient = ⌊N/k⌋. This gives the maximum number of complete groups.</description>
  <example>With 25 tokens and each group needing 4 tokens, ⌊25/4⌋=6 full groups.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Apply the remainder to check for leftover resources. Remainder = N mod k indicates how many items remain unused after forming full groups.</description>
  <example>Continuing the 25 tokens example, 25 mod 4=1, so 1 token is left over.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify that the total resource count meets or exceeds the required amount. If N < k, no full groups can be formed.</description>
  <example>If you only have 3 tokens and each group needs 5, then 3/5=0 full groups, and you cannot proceed.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When tasks are split evenly over a fixed number of days, divide the total count by the number of days. This gives the average daily workload. Ensure the total is divisible by the days or handle remainders appropriately.</description>
  <example>Suppose you have 20 tasks and 5 days. Divide 20 by 5 to get 4 tasks per day. If you had 21 tasks and 5 days, you’d get 4 tasks per day with 1 leftover task.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the floor function to distribute tasks evenly when remainders exist. Compute total tasks ÷ days = q with remainder r, then assign q tasks to each day and handle the r extra tasks by rotating or adjusting as needed.</description>
  <example>With 21 tasks and 5 days, 21 ÷ 5 = 4 remainder 1. Assign 4 tasks each day, then give the extra task to one day, e.g. Day 1 gets 5 tasks, others get 4.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Break the problem into categories and sum them before dividing. First, add all individual counts to get the total, then apply the division. This clarifies the total workload and avoids mixing categories.</description>
  <example>If you have 6 dogs, 3 cats, 2 birds, and 10 horses, sum to 21 animals. Then divide 21 by 7 days to get 3 animals per day.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for integer results and remainders. If the division yields a non-integer, reconsider the number of days or adjust the schedule to accommodate fractional tasks. This ensures a feasible plan.</description>
  <example>Dividing 21 tasks by 4 days gives 5.25 tasks per day, which isn’t practical. You might need to add a day or adjust the workload to make it an integer.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use a simple table or list to track daily assignments. List days in one column and tasks in another, then fill in the count for each day. This helps visualize the schedule and catch mistakes.</description>
  <example>Days: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5; Tasks: 4, 4, 4, 4, 5. Fill in the table row by row to see how tasks are distributed over the week.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert any time-based rate into a per-unit rate by dividing the total amount by the total time. This lets you compare different rates on a common basis.</description>
  <example>For instance, if a machine produces 120 units in 4 hours, its rate is 120/4 = 30 units per hour.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute total consumption by multiplying the per-unit rate by the total time. This gives the overall amount needed for the entire period.</description>
  <example>Using the 30 units/hour rate for 8 hours yields 30 × 8 = 240 units total.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When resources come in fixed-size containers, divide the total requirement by the container size to find how many containers are needed. Always round up to cover any remainder.</description>
  <example>If you need 240 units and each container holds 60 units, 240/60 = 4 containers are required.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always perform a sanity check: verify that the computed number of containers is at least 1 and that the total consumption does not exceed the capacity of the computed containers.</description>
  <example>After finding 4 containers, confirm 4 × 60 = 240 units, which matches the requirement, and ensure no fractional container is used.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>Convert percentage statements into decimal multipliers by dividing by 100. This lets you multiply the total quantity by the decimal to find the portion.</description>
  <example>“40% of the items” becomes 0.40 × total. For instance, 0.40 × 100 = 40 items.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Compute the remaining quantity after a removal by subtracting the removed portion from the original total: remaining = total – (percentage × total).</description>
  <example>From 100 items, if 0.40 are removed, remaining = 100 – (0.40 × 100) = 60 items.</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>Convert a fraction into a decimal by dividing numerator by denominator. Use this to multiply the remaining quantity by the fraction for the next harvest.</description>
  <example>“2/3 of the remaining” becomes (2 ÷ 3) × remaining. For 60 items, 2/3 × 60 = 40 items.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>After multiple removals, the final unharvested amount is the original total minus the sum of all removed portions. This avoids recomputing each step from scratch.</description>
  <example>Original 100, first removed 0.40 × 100 = 40, second removed 2/3 × 60 = 40, so unharvested = 100 – (40 + 40) = 20.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>Always check that your final answer is nonnegative and does not exceed the original total. This guards against arithmetic or rounding errors.</description>
  <example>If you get –10 items unharvested, recheck your subtraction steps. If you get 120 items, recheck your total and removed sums.</example>
</note6>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “k times” another, represent it as k·(sum of the other parts). This captures proportional relationships directly.</description>
  <example>Suppose two people contribute A and B, and a third contributes k times their total. The third’s contribution is k·(A + B).</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Sum all known contributions before applying any multiplier. This ensures you use the correct base amount for proportional calculations.</description>
  <example>If contributions are A, B, and C, first compute S = A + B + C, then apply any multiplier to S or to C separately as needed.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When an additional amount is added after contributions, include it in the final sum before any further operations. This prevents missing contributions in later steps.</description>
  <example>After computing S = A + B + C, if D is added later, the new total is S + D, which you then use for any subsequent calculations.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use parentheses to group terms correctly when combining sums and multipliers. This avoids misordering operations and ensures the correct result.</description>
  <example>For contributions A, B, and C, and a multiplier k, compute k·(A + B + C) rather than k·A + B + C to maintain the intended proportionality.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify that the final result matches the problem’s description. Check that no contributions were omitted and that the multiplier was applied to the correct sum.</description>
  <example>After computing the lawyer’s contribution as k·(A + B + C + D), compare it to the problem statement to ensure consistency with all given amounts.</example>

<note1>
    <description>Convert a percentage to a decimal by dividing by 100. This is essential for applying percentages in calculations.</description>
    <example>For a 40% success rate, compute 40 ÷ 100 = 0.40 before multiplying by any total.</example>
  </note2>
  <note2>
    <description>Use the formula “part = percentage × total” to find the number of successes or failures. This works for any percentage-based count.</description>
    <example>With a 60% success rate on 50 trials, successes = 0.60 × 50 = 30.</example>
  </note3>
  <note3>
    <description>When asked for the complement (e.g., losses or failures), subtract the computed part from the total. This leverages the fact that part + complement = total.</description>
    <example>If 30 out of 50 trials succeed, then failures = 50 – 30 = 20.</example>
  </note4>
  <note5>
    <description>Always check that the result is an integer when counting discrete items. If not, re-examine rounding or the problem setup.</description>
    <example>After computing 0.75 × 20 = 15, confirm 15 is an integer; if it were 15.2, reconsider the percentage or total.</example>
  </note6>
  <note6>
    <description>Verify by reversing the calculation: multiply the complement back by the total and add to the original part to ensure it sums to the total.</description>
    <example>For 15 successes out of 20, compute 15 + (20 – 15) = 20, confirming consistency.</example>
  </note7>

1. <note1>
  <description>Break the total period into segments where the rate changes. Identify each segment’s duration and rate, then compute each segment’s cost separately.</description>
  <example>For a 2-year subscription with rates $r₁ for the first m months, $r₂ for the next n months, and $r₃ for the remaining t months, split into three segments: (m·r₁), (n·r₂), (t·r₃).</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Convert the total time into the same unit as the rate (e.g., months). If the rate is per month but the time is given in years, multiply years by 12 to get months.</description>
  <example>Two years equals 24 months. If the first segment is 6 months, the remaining time is 24–6=18 months, which you then use in the next rate calculation.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the arithmetic progression formula when rates increase linearly. If the first term is a, the common difference is d, and there are k terms, the sum is k/2·[2a + (k–1)d].</description>
  <example>For 3 months at rates $a, $a+d, $a+2d, the total is 3/2·[2a + 2d] = 3(a + d).</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Apply the weighted average rate when multiple segments have different rates. Compute (Σ(segment duration·rate)) / (Σsegment durations).</description>
  <example>With segments of durations d₁, d₂, d₃ and rates r₁, r₂, r₃, the average rate is (d₁r₁ + d₂r₂ + d₃r₃) / (d₁ + d₂ + d₃).</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Perform a sanity check by comparing your result to a simpler estimate. For instance, if all segments had the same rate, the cost would be total duration × that rate; your computed cost should be close.</description>
  <example>If the subscription cost $15 per month for 24 months, the estimate is 24·15=360. If your computed cost is 350, it’s reasonable; if it’s far off, recheck segment boundaries.</example>

Repeating the process of using leftover ink to make new pens is a classic “geometric series” or “floor division” problem. Each time you use ink from a certain number of empty pens to make one new pen, you reduce the count of empty pens by that number and gain one new pen. Summing these gains over iterations gives the total pens.

weekdayPattern: Identify which days have the same class schedule and which have different schedules. Grouping by day type simplifies counting.
hourPerDay: For each day type, compute the total hours by multiplying the number of classes by the duration per class.
totalWeek: Multiply the sum of daily hours by the number of weeks in the term.
checkConsistency: Ensure that the sum of hours across all day types equals the total hours counted by the grouped method.
averageDaily: Optionally, compute the average hours per day by dividing total hours by the number of days in the term.

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute total items by multiplying quantity per unit by number of units. This applies whenever you have a fixed amount per container or batch.</description>
  <example>With 5 boxes each holding 8 items, total items = 5 × 8 = 40.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use division to find how many full groups of a given size fit into a total. This gives the count of complete groups.</description>
  <example>Given 40 items and groups of 10, number of full groups = 40 ÷ 10 = 4.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Apply the ceiling function when you need at least one full group even if there’s a remainder. This ensures you account for leftover items.</description>
  <example>With 40 items and groups of 10, ceiling(40 ÷ 10) = 4, so you need 4 full groups.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for remainders by computing the remainder of the division. This helps verify if any items are left unused.</description>
  <example>40 ÷ 10 leaves a remainder of 0, so no items remain; if it were 41, remainder = 1.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify your result by multiplying the number of groups by the group size and adding any remainder to ensure it matches the total.</description>
  <example>4 groups of 10 give 40, plus 0 remainder = 40, confirming the calculation is correct.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Translate verbal relationships into algebraic equations by assigning variables to each unknown and expressing each statement as an equation. This creates a system of equations that can be solved systematically.</description>
  <example>Suppose three quantities A, B, and C satisfy “A + B + C = S” and “B = k·C.” Assign variables A, B, C, write A + B + C = S, and B = k·C. These two equations form the basis for solving the system.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use substitution to reduce a system of equations: solve one equation for one variable and substitute into the others. This simplifies the system to fewer variables.</description>
  <example>From B = k·C, substitute B into A + B + C = S to get A + k·C + C = S, yielding A + (k+1)·C = S. Now you have two equations in A and C, which can be solved together.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Apply the sum-of-variables condition to express one variable in terms of the total and the others. This often reduces the number of unknowns by one.</description>
  <example>Given A + B + C = S and B = k·C, substitute B into the sum to get A + k·C + C = S, so A = S – (k+1)·C. Now only C remains as the primary unknown.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for consistency by ensuring all derived expressions satisfy the original conditions. Substitute back to verify no contradictions arise.</description>
  <example>After finding A = S – (k+1)·C and B = k·C, substitute into A + B + C = S to confirm S – (k+1)·C + k·C + C = S, which simplifies to S = S, confirming consistency.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use the sum of coefficients to find the ratio of variables when their sum is known. If A + B + C = S and B = k·C, then A + (k+1)·C = S, so C = S / (1 + k + 1) and A = S – (k+1)·C.</description>
  <example>With A + B + C = S and B = k·C, the total weight of B and C is (k+1)·C, so C = S / (k+2) and A = S – (k+1)·[S/(k+2)]. This directly yields each variable in terms of S and k.</example>

Define Variables: Assign a symbol to each unknown quantity (e.g., let x = length of Movie C, y = length of Movie B, z = length of Movie A).
Translate Phrases: Convert comparative statements into algebraic equations (e.g., “one-fifth the length” becomes z = (1/5)y, “5 minutes longer” becomes y = x + 5).
Substitute and Solve: Use substitution to express all variables in terms of one variable, then solve the resulting equation.
Check Units: Ensure all quantities use the same unit (minutes, hours) before combining or comparing.
Validate: Plug the found values back into the original statements to confirm consistency.

1. <note1>
  <description>When items are removed from a total, subtract the removed quantity from the original total. This applies to any scenario where you lose or remove a known number of items from a known stock.</description>
  <example>Suppose a store has T₁ items and sells S₁ of them. The remaining stock is T₁ – S₁. For instance, if T₁ = 100 and S₁ = 20, then 100 – 20 = 80 items remain.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>For multiple categories, compute each category’s remaining separately and then sum the results. This ensures you account for different types of items independently before combining totals.</description>
  <example>Imagine Category A has T₂ items and loses S₂, while Category B has T₃ items and loses S₃. The total remaining is (T₂ – S₂) + (T₃ – S₃). For example, if T₂ = 50, S₂ = 10, T₃ = 30, S₃ = 5, then (50 – 10) + (30 – 5) = 40 + 25 = 65.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the complement principle: instead of subtracting removed items, add the items that remain. This can simplify mental arithmetic by focusing on what stays rather than what goes.</description>
  <example>If a shelf originally holds T₄ books and S₄ are taken away, the remaining books are T₄ – S₄. Equivalently, if R₄ = T₄ – S₄, then R₄ books remain. For instance, if T₄ = 80 and S₄ = 15, then 80 – 15 = 65, or equivalently, 80 – 15 = 65.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always verify your subtraction by adding the removed quantity back to the result. This check helps catch arithmetic errors and ensures consistency.</description>
  <example>After finding R₅ = T₅ – S₅, confirm that R₅ + S₅ = T₅. For example, if T₅ = 70 and S₅ = 20, then R₅ = 50. Checking: 50 + 20 = 70, which matches the original total.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Watch for common pitfalls: ensure you subtract the correct number of items from each category and avoid mixing up categories. Mislabeling or miscounting can lead to incorrect totals.</description>
  <example>If you mistakenly subtract S₆ from Category A when it should be from Category B, you’ll get an incorrect remainder. Always double-check which category each subtraction applies to before finalizing the total.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Translate each comparative statement into an algebraic equation by assigning a variable to each unknown and expressing “older by” or “younger by” as subtraction or addition. This creates a system of linear equations.</description>
  <example>Suppose A is k years older than B and C is m years younger than A. Assign A=a, B=b, C=c. Then write a = b + k and c = a – m.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use substitution to reduce the system: solve one equation for one variable and substitute into the others. This turns multiple equations into a single-variable equation.</description>
  <example>From a = b + k, substitute into c = a – m to get c = (b + k) – m, yielding c = b + (k – m).</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Apply the given absolute value or direct relation to find one variable’s value. Once you have an equation like c = b + d, plug in the known value of c to solve for b.</description>
  <example>If c is known to be n and c = b + d, then b = n – d, directly giving the value of b.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Verify consistency by back-substituting all found values into the original equations. This ensures no arithmetic or sign errors occurred.</description>
  <example>After finding b, compute a = b + k and c = a – m, then check that these match the given relations and any absolute values.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Check for extraneous solutions by ensuring all ages or values are positive and satisfy any ordering constraints (e.g., “older than” must be positive). Discard any that violate these.</description>
  <example>If a computed age is negative, revisit the equations; if it contradicts “A is older than B,” adjust signs or re-examine the setup.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>When a process has multiple constant rates, compute the total output by multiplying each rate by its duration and summing the results. This works because total = rate × time for each segment.</description>
  <example>Suppose a pump removes 3 units/hour for 2 hours, then 6 units/hour for 3 hours. Total = (3×2) + (6×3) = 6 + 18 = 24 units.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Use proportional relationships to express one rate in terms of another. If rate B is k times rate A, then B = k·A, simplifying comparisons and calculations.</description>
  <example>If a machine produces 5 widgets per minute, and another produces twice as many, then the second produces 2×5 = 10 widgets per minute.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>When rates increase by a constant factor each step, model them as a geometric sequence: r, r·k, r·k², …, then sum over the number of steps. The sum S = r·(1 – kⁿ)/(1 – k) for k ≠ 1.</description>
  <example>For a process with rates 4, 4·2, 4·2² over 3 days, S = 4·(1 – 2³)/(1 – 2) = 4·(1 – 8)/(–1) = 4·7 = 28.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Always check units consistency: ensure rate units (e.g., liters/day) match time units (e.g., days) before multiplying. Mismatched units lead to incorrect totals.</description>
  <example>If a device removes 5 L/hour and you run it for 2 hours, multiply 5 L/hour × 2 hours = 10 L. If you mistakenly used hours instead of days, you’d get 10 L/hour × 2 days = 20 L, which is wrong.</example>
</note5>
<note6>
  <description>After computing totals, verify by estimating or using a simpler case. A rough estimate can catch off-by-one or unit errors before finalizing.</description>
  <example>For rates 2, 4, 8 over 3 days, a quick estimate is (2+4+8)×3 = 14×3 = 42. If your detailed calculation gives 45, you know something is off.</example>
</note6>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a problem states one quantity is a fixed amount less (or more) than another, express that relationship as an equation: if A is k less than B, then A = B – k. This converts verbal conditions into algebraic form.</description>
  <example>Suppose a widget costs $k less than a gadget. If the gadget costs G, then the widget’s cost is W = G – k. This equation can be used to find W once G is known.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the total-cost equation: if multiple items cost C₁, C₂, …, Cₙ, then their sum equals the total T, i.e. C₁ + C₂ + … + Cₙ = T. This is the foundation for solving for unknown individual costs.</description>
  <example>Three items cost C₁, C₂, and C₃, and together they cost T. Then C₁ + C₂ + C₃ = T. If two costs are known, subtract their sum from T to find the third.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When multiple identical items are involved, introduce a variable for one item and multiply by the count. If n identical items each cost x, their total is n·x. This simplifies handling repeated quantities.</description>
  <example>Five identical gadgets each cost x. Then the total cost is 5x. If the total is T, set 5x = T and solve for x.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>After forming equations, isolate the unknown by performing inverse operations: add or subtract to move constants, then divide or multiply to solve for the variable. This systematic approach ensures correct solutions.</description>
  <example>From 5x = T, divide both sides by 5 to get x = T/5. Similarly, from A = B – k, add k to both sides to get B = A + k.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify your solution by substituting it back into the original conditions. This check catches algebraic mistakes and ensures consistency with the problem’s wording.</description>
  <example>If you find x = T/5, plug it into 5x = T to confirm equality. If A = B – k, check that A + k = B. Any mismatch indicates an error.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert all time units to a single unit before adding or comparing. Use the conversion factors: 1 minute = 60 seconds, 1 hour = 3600 seconds, etc. This ensures consistency in your calculations.</description>
  <example>Suppose a task takes 2 minutes and 30 seconds. Convert to seconds: 2 min × 60 s/min + 30 s = 150 s. Then you can add this to other time values in seconds without error.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a process consists of multiple sequential steps, the total time is the sum of the individual step times. This applies to any workflow with distinct phases.</description>
  <example>If one step takes 150 s and the next takes 45 s, the total time is 150 s + 45 s = 195 s. You simply add each step’s duration to get the overall time.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>For repetitive tasks, multiply the time per task by the number of tasks. This is useful when each task is identical in duration.</description>
  <example>If each of 10 identical tasks takes 195 s, the total time is 10 × 195 s = 1950 s. Multiply the per-task time by the count to get the total.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the unitary method to find the time for one unit and then scale up. First determine the time for one item, then multiply by the total number of items.</description>
  <example>If 10 items take 1950 s, then one item takes 1950 s ÷ 10 = 195 s. For 80 items, multiply 195 s × 80 = 15600 s.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>After computing a total time, convert it back to a more familiar unit (e.g., minutes or hours) by dividing by the appropriate factor. This makes the result easier to interpret.</description>
  <example>If the total time is 15600 s, convert to minutes: 15600 s ÷ 60 s/min = 260 min. Then convert to hours: 260 min ÷ 60 min/h = 4.33 h.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When one quantity is described as “k fewer than” another, represent it as Q₁ – k. This captures the difference directly in algebraic form.</description>
  <example>For instance, if A has 100 items and B has 20 fewer, then B = 100 – 20 = 80. This sets up the initial relationship for further operations.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Translating “gives” or “receives” into algebra: if X gives y units to Y, then X → X – y and Y → Y + y. This models transfers clearly.</description>
  <example>Suppose X has 80 units and gives 10 to Y. Then X becomes 80 – 10 = 70, and Y becomes Y + 10. This keeps track of each party’s new count.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>After transfers, compute the new difference by subtracting the updated quantities: (Q₁_new – Q₂_new). This yields the final comparative gap.</description>
  <example>With X = 70 and Y = 80 + 10 = 90, the difference is 70 – 90 = –20, meaning Y has 20 more than X. The sign indicates which side is larger.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check for sign conventions: a negative result means the second quantity is larger, while a positive result means the first is larger. Clarify “fewer” vs. “more” in context.</description>
  <example>If the difference is –15, it means the second party has 15 more, not fewer. Thus, “fewer” apples would be the absolute value, 15.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use absolute value when the question asks for “how many fewer” or “how many more,” regardless of sign. This ensures the answer is nonnegative.</description>
  <example>From a difference of –15, the number of fewer apples is |–15| = 15. This aligns with the question’s wording of “fewer.”</example>
</note5>

<cheatsheet>
  <note1>
    <description>Compute the percentage error by dividing the observed deviation by the intended value and multiplying by 100. This gives the percent by which the actual differs from the target.</description>
    <example>For an intended value of 100 and an observed value of 110, the error is (110–100)/100×100=10%.</example>
  </note2>
  <note3>
    <description>Convert a percentage error into a decimal multiplier by adding or subtracting the percent (as a decimal) from 1. Use 1±p/100 to scale any intended value.</description>
    <example>A 10% overestimate corresponds to a multiplier of 1+0.10=1.10; a 10% underestimate uses 1–0.10=0.90.</example>
  </note3>
  <note4>
    <description>Apply the multiplier to the intended value to obtain the observed value. This directly accounts for the consistent percentage shift.</description>
    <example>With a 10% overestimate multiplier 1.10, an intended 100 becomes 100×1.10=110.</example>
  </note5>
  <note6>
    <description>When the target is unknown but the observed value and error percent are known, divide the observed value by the multiplier to recover the intended value.</description>
    <example>If an observed 110 corresponds to a 10% overestimate (multiplier 1.10), then the intended value is 110/1.10=100.</example>
  </note7>
  <note8>
    <description>Always check that the computed intended or observed value makes sense in context (e.g., non-negative, within reasonable bounds) to catch sign or rounding errors.</description>
    <example>After computing an intended value of 100 from an observed 110 with a 10% overestimate, verify that 100×1.10 indeed equals 110.</example>
  </note9>
</cheatsheet>

<note1>
  <description>When a fraction of a group is selected, compute the count by multiplying the total size by the fraction. This applies to any subset defined by a proportional rule.</description>
  <example>For a group of size N, if one-third are chosen, the count is N × (1/3). For instance, if N = 12, then 12 × (1/3) = 4.</example>
</note2>
<note2>
  <description>When multiple groups have different fractions selected, compute each separately and then sum the results to find the total number of selected items across all groups.</description>
  <example>Group A has size N₁ and one-fourth are chosen (N₁ × 1/4), Group B has size N₂ and one-fifth are chosen (N₂ × 1/5). The total selected is (N₁ × 1/4) + (N₂ × 1/5).</example>
</note3>
<note3>
  <description>When two or more categories overlap, use the inclusion-exclusion principle: Total = (A) + (B) – (A ∩ B). This ensures double-counting of common elements is corrected.</description>
  <example>If 5 students are in both choir and drama, and 8 are in choir, 7 are in drama, then the total in at least one is 8 + 7 – 5 = 10.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>To find the number of items not in a particular subset, subtract the count of that subset from the total. This is the complement principle in set theory.</description>
  <example>Given a total of N items and k items in a subset, the number not in that subset is N – k. For example, if N = 20 and k = 6, then 20 – 6 = 14.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>When extracurricular activities or categories do not affect a primary count, treat those categories as independent and ignore their overlap or total when computing the primary subset.</description>
  <example>If the number of students in choir or drama does not change the count of students on the varsity team, you can compute the varsity team count solely from the fraction of the total and ignore any overlap or additional categories.</example>
</note6>
