1. <note1>
  <description>Convert total payments into a single sum by adding the advance payment to the product of the number of installments and the installment amount. This gives the total cost of each offer.</description>
  <example>For an offer with an advance of A and n installments of P each, the total cost is A + n·P. For instance, if A=100 and n=4, P=50, then total=100+4·50=300.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the formula for the sum of an arithmetic series when installments form an arithmetic progression: S = n·(first term + last term)/2. This is useful if installments increase or decrease by a constant amount.</description>
  <example>If installments are 20, 25, 30, 35, then n=4, first=20, last=35, so S=4·(20+35)/2=4·55/2=110.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Compare two total costs by subtracting the smaller from the larger. This yields the cost difference between the two offers.</description>
  <example>If Offer A costs 300 and Offer B costs 250, then the difference is 300–250=50.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for hidden fees or conditions (e.g., interest, late fees) that aren’t included in the stated advance and installments. Always read the fine print to avoid miscalculations.</description>
  <example>If an offer states “no interest” but the installments are higher than the advertised price, there may be an unmentioned interest charge. Always verify.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify your result by re-deriving the total cost using a different method (e.g., summing each installment separately) to catch arithmetic errors.</description>
  <example>For installments 50, 50, 50, 50, sum=50+50+50+50=200. If you previously got 250, you know there was a mistake.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert a percentage into a decimal by dividing by 100. This lets you multiply it with totals to find fractional amounts.</description>
  <example>For a 30% share, compute 30/100 = 0.30. Then multiply 0.30 by the total to get the portion.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When two people share a cost equally, each pays half. For any equal split, use 1/2 or 0.5 of the total.</description>
  <example>If the total is T, each person pays T × 0.5. For instance, if T = 200, each pays 100.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Compute a person’s share of a total cost by multiplying the total by their percentage or fraction. This applies to any proportional split.</description>
  <example>With a total of T and a share of p%, the amount is T × (p/100). For p = 40 and T = 500, the share is 200.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>When a total is divided into equal parts over a period, find the per-period amount by dividing the total by the number of periods.</description>
  <example>If a total of T is spread over n weeks, each week’s share is T ÷ n. For T = 300 and n = 5, each week is 60.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check that the sum of individual shares equals the total. This ensures no rounding or arithmetic errors occurred.</description>
  <example>After computing shares S₁ and S₂, verify S₁ + S₂ = T. If T = 400 and shares are 250 and 150, they sum to 400.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a total quantity is equally divided into k groups, each group’s share is total ÷ k. This applies to any equal partitioning problem.</description>
  <example>Suppose 120 items are split into 4 equal piles. Each pile has 120 ÷ 4 = 30 items.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>To find a percentage p% of a quantity N, compute (p/100) × N. This converts a percentage into a fraction of the whole.</description>
  <example>For 100 units, 25% is (25/100) × 100 = 25 units.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>When a group is split into two parts (e.g., girls and boys), the other part is the complement: 100% – p%. Use this to find the remaining portion.</description>
  <example>If 40% of a group are girls, then 60% are boys, since 100% – 40% = 60%.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always verify that the sum of all parts equals 100% (or the total quantity). This check prevents misclassification or miscalculation.</description>
  <example>If 30% are A and 50% are B, then 30% + 50% = 80%, so the remaining 20% must be accounted for.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>When external entities (like teachers) are not included in a count, exclude them from the total before applying any percentage or division. This ensures accurate subgroup calculations.</description>
  <example>If 80 students plus 5 teachers total 85, but only students are counted, then 40% of 80 is 32, not 37.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a problem states that a break or pause does not affect the total distance, ignore any time-related information and focus solely on the distances covered. This ensures you only use the given distance data to compute the required segment.</description>
  <example>Suppose a runner takes a 5-minute break during a 10-mile run, but the problem says the break didn’t change the total distance. You should compute the distance between two points by adding the two given segments (e.g., 3 miles + 4 miles = 7 miles) and ignore the break’s duration.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Break a continuous journey into segments at the given stopping points. Label each segment with its distance and use these labels to form equations or sums when needed.</description>
  <example>For a 20-mile trip with stops at 5 miles and 12 miles, label the segments as S₁ = 5 miles, S₂ = 7 miles (from 5 to 12), and S₃ = 8 miles (from 12 to 20). You can then compute any required distance by summing or comparing these segments.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the total distance minus the known segments to find the unknown segment. If the total is T and you know two segments A and B, then the third segment is T – (A + B).</description>
  <example>In a 30-mile route, you know the first segment is 10 miles and the last segment is 12 miles. The middle segment is 30 – (10 + 12) = 8 miles.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always verify that the sum of all computed segments equals the total distance. This check catches arithmetic errors and ensures consistency in your solution.</description>
  <example>If you find segments of 6 miles, 9 miles, and 10 miles, check that 6 + 9 + 10 = 25 miles matches the given total. If it doesn’t, re-examine your segment labels or calculations.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Be cautious of problems that mix distance and time information. If the problem explicitly states that time does not affect distance, treat time data as irrelevant and avoid incorporating it into your distance calculations.</description>
  <example>A cyclist takes a 15-minute break during a 25-mile ride, but the problem says the break didn’t change the total distance. You should compute the distance between two points by adding the given segments (e.g., 10 miles + 12 miles = 22 miles) and ignore the break’s duration.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert all time units to a single unit (e.g., minutes) before summing. This avoids unit mismatches and simplifies arithmetic.</description>
  <example>Convert 1 hour to 60 minutes and 30 minutes to 30 minutes. Then add 60 + 30 + 30 + 60 + 30 = 210 minutes total.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Model each activity as a variable times its duration. For example, if x 30-minute shows are watched, represent that as 30·x minutes.</description>
  <example>On Wednesday, if x 30-minute shows are watched, write the time as 30·x. On Friday, two 1-hour shows become 2·60 = 120 minutes.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Set up a linear equation by summing all modeled durations and equating to the total known time. This captures the relationship between variables and the total.</description>
  <example>Summing known times and the variable term gives 60 + 30 + 30·x + 60 + 30 + 120 = 7·60. Simplify to 300 + 30x = 420.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Solve the linear equation for the unknown variable. Use standard algebraic steps: combine like terms, isolate the variable, and divide.</description>
  <example>From 300 + 30x = 420, subtract 300 to get 30x = 120, then divide by 30 to find x = 4.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify the solution by substituting back into the original equation and checking that all durations sum to the given total.</description>
  <example>Substitute x = 4 into 30·x = 120 minutes, then sum 60 + 30 + 120 + 60 + 30 + 120 = 420 minutes, matching the total.</example>

<note1>
  <description>Compute the subtotal by summing the unit prices of each item multiplied by their quantities. This gives the total cost before any fees or discounts.</description>
  <example>For 3 items priced at p₁, p₂, p₃ with quantities q₁, q₂, q₃, the subtotal is p₁·q₁ + p₂·q₂ + p₃·q₃.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Apply a percentage fee by multiplying the subtotal by the fee rate (expressed as a decimal). This yields the additional charge for services like delivery.</description>
  <example>With a 15% service fee on a subtotal S, the fee is 0.15·S.</example>
</note1>
<note3>
  <description>Handle free items by excluding them from both the subtotal and any fee calculations. Only paid items contribute to the total cost.</description>
  <example>If 2 items are free, their unit prices and quantities are ignored when computing S and the service fee.</example>
</note1>
<note4>
  <description>Compute a tip by adding a fixed amount to the subtotal. This is a straightforward addition of a per-item or per-order tip.</description>
  <example>Adding a $2.00 tip to a subtotal S results in S + 2.00.</example>
</note1>
<note5>
  <description>When a discount is not applicable, treat it as zero. The final total remains the sum of subtotal, fees, and any fixed additions.</description>
  <example>If a 10% discount is invalid, the total is subtotal + service fee + tip without subtracting any discount.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert all time units to a single base unit (e.g. minutes) to simplify rate calculations. This ensures consistency when adding or comparing rates over different intervals.</description>
  <example>Suppose a process takes 1 hour and 30 minutes. Convert to minutes: 1 h × 60 min/h + 30 min = 90 min. Then compute rates per minute for further analysis.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute net production rate by subtracting loss rate from generation rate. If you produce P units per time unit and lose L units per time unit, the net rate is (P – L) units per time unit.</description>
  <example>Machine makes 50 units/hour but loses 10 units/hour. Net rate = 50 – 10 = 40 units/hour. Use this net rate in further time or quantity calculations.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the linear relation Q = R × T to find time or quantity. Here Q is the total amount, R is the rate, and T is the time. Rearrange as T = Q/R or Q = R × T as needed.</description>
  <example>To reach 120 units at a net rate of 40 units/hour, compute T = 120 / 40 = 3 hours. This gives the time required to accumulate the desired quantity.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Account for periodic events by treating them as discrete intervals. If an event occurs every k units of time and has effect E, compute its total effect over T as ⌊T/k⌋ × E.</description>
  <example>A process loses 2 units every 15 minutes. Over 60 minutes, it occurs 60/15 = 4 times, so total loss = 4 × 2 = 8 units. Subtract this from the generated amount.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Verify results by plugging back into the original scenario. Check that the computed time or quantity aligns with all given rates and periodic events to catch arithmetic or unit errors.</description>
  <example>After finding T = 3 hours, recalculate net production: 40 units/hour × 3 h = 120 units. Confirm this matches the target and that periodic losses are correctly subtracted.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a quantity is split into two equal parts, each part is the total divided by 2. This applies to any scenario where a whole is evenly partitioned into two segments.</description>
  <example>Suppose a total of T units is split into two equal halves. Then each half is T/2 units. For instance, if T=100, each half is 50 units.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When one segment’s value is a multiple k of another, express the first segment as k·(second segment). This captures proportional relationships between segments.</description>
  <example>If the second segment is S units and the first segment is twice as large, then the first segment is 2·S units. For example, if S=10, the first segment is 20 units.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When a daily expense or cost is subtracted from a daily saving, compute net daily savings as (daily saving) – (daily expense). This gives the actual amount saved each day.</description>
  <example>If someone saves D dollars per day but spends E dollars on a hobby, their net savings per day is D – E. For instance, if D=20 and E=5, net savings is 15 dollars per day.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>When a total target is split into two segments, set up the equation (segment1) + (segment2) = total. This ensures the sum of both parts meets the required total.</description>
  <example>For a total target T, if segment1 is A and segment2 is B, then A + B = T. For example, if T=100, and A=40, then B must be 60 to meet the target.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>After forming an equation, solve for the unknown by isolating it. Use inverse operations (addition/subtraction, multiplication/division) to find the value of the variable.</description>
  <example>Given 2·X + 3 = 11, subtract 3 from both sides to get 2·X = 8, then divide by 2 to find X = 4.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the total count to find unknown group sizes by subtracting known parts from the total. If a group has N items and you know K of them, the rest are N–K. This works whenever you have a fixed total and some items are already accounted for.</description>
  <example>Suppose a class has 20 students and 12 are girls. Then the number of boys is 20–12=8. This method applies to any scenario where you know the total and one subgroup’s size.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Apply the complement rule for percentages: if a group is P% of the total, the other part is (100–P)%. This lets you find the size of the complementary subgroup without extra calculations.</description>
  <example>In a class of 20 students, if 50% are girls, then 50% are boys. So the number of boys is 50% of 20, which is 10. This approach is useful whenever you know one subgroup’s percentage.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When multiple groups share the same total size, sum the known counts across all groups to find the overall total. Then subtract this sum from the grand total to find the remaining group’s size.</description>
  <example>Three classes each have 20 students, so the school has 60 students in total. If the first class has 12 girls and the second has 12 girls, then across two classes there are 24 girls. Subtracting from 60 gives 36 students in the third class, of which you can find the number of boys by other means.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the sum of all subgroup counts to verify totals. If you have several subgroups (e.g., boys, girls, long-haired, short-haired), ensure their sum equals the overall total. This check catches arithmetic or logical errors.</description>
  <example>In a class of 20 students, if you count 12 girls and 8 boys, the sum is 20, matching the class size. If you later find 7 long-haired girls and 5 short-haired girls, their sum (12) also matches the total number of girls, confirming consistency.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Be cautious of overlapping categories: if a subgroup is counted in multiple categories, subtract overlaps to avoid double-counting. Always ensure each item is counted exactly once.</description>
  <example>If you count 12 girls and then separately count 7 long-haired students, but 4 of those long-haired students are girls, you must subtract the overlap: 7–4=3 long-haired girls. Then the total girls count remains 12, avoiding an inflated total.</example>
Let x be the amount Brad receives. Then Jeff receives 4x. The total is x + 4x = 5x = 100, so x = 20. Jeff’s share is 4·20 = 80.

<note1>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “a% more than” another, convert the percentage to a multiplier by adding 1 to the decimal form of the percentage. This gives the factor by which the base quantity is scaled.</description>
  <example>For a 20% increase, use multiplier 1 + 0.20 = 1.20. If the base is B, the increased amount is B × 1.20.</example>
</note1>
  <note2>
  <description>Translate a percentage increase into a linear equation: if the base is B and the increase is p%, then the new quantity N satisfies N = B × (1 + p/100). This directly models the relationship.</description>
  <example>With B = 100 and p = 30%, write N = 100 × (1 + 0.30) = 130.</example>
</note2>
  <note3>
  <description>Always check that the percentage increase is applied to the correct base. Mixing up the base can lead to incorrect scaling and results.</description>
  <example>If you mistakenly apply a 25% increase to a quantity that is already increased by 25%, you get a different result than applying it to the original base.</example>
</note3>
  <note4>
  <description>When combining multiple quantities, sum them after converting each to its final form. Ensure all quantities use the same base or multiplier before adding.</description>
  <example>If you have A = B × 1.10 and B = 200, then total = A + B = (200 × 1.10) + 200 = 420.</example>
</note4>
  <note5>
  <description>Use dimensional analysis to verify consistency: ensure that all terms in the sum have the same unit (e.g., same type of quantity) before adding.</description>
  <example>Adding “number of apples” to “number of oranges” is invalid; both must be counts of the same fruit type.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
    <description>Convert a fraction of a total into an absolute quantity by multiplying the fraction by the total. This works because a fraction represents a part of the whole.</description>
    <example>For a total of T items and a fraction f, the part is f × T. For instance, if T = 100 and f = 1/4, then the part is (1/4) × 100 = 25.</example>
  </note2>
  <note3>
    <description>Find the remaining portion by subtracting the completed fraction from 1. This gives the fraction of the total that remains to be done.</description>
    <example>If you have completed f of the work, the remaining fraction is 1 – f. For example, if f = 1/3, then the remaining fraction is 1 – 1/3 = 2/3.</example>
  </note3>
  <note4>
    <description>Compute the remaining quantity by multiplying the remaining fraction by the total. This directly yields the number of items left.</description>
    <example>With a total of T and a remaining fraction r, the remaining items are r × T. For instance, if T = 150 and r = 2/3, then the remaining items are (2/3) × 150 = 100.</example>
  </note4>
  <note5>
    <description>Always check that the computed remaining quantity is non-negative and does not exceed the total. This ensures the result is valid.</description>
    <example>If you calculate r × T = –10 for a total T = 50, you know something went wrong because a negative remainder is impossible. A valid remainder must satisfy 0 ≤ r × T ≤ T.</example>
  </note5>
  <note6>
    <description>Use a sanity check by verifying that the sum of completed and remaining parts equals the total. This confirms consistency in your calculations.</description>
    <example>If you have completed f × T and remaining r × T, check that f × T + r × T = T. For example, if f = 1/3 and r = 2/3, then (1/3)T + (2/3)T = T, confirming correctness.</example>
  </note6>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a quantity is described as “k times” another, represent it as k·(original quantity). This captures proportional relationships succinctly.</description>
  <example>For instance, if one segment lasts t units and another lasts three times as long, write the second segment as 3·t.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Sum multiple expressions by combining like terms: a·x + b·x = (a + b)·x. This simplifies total calculations when several parts share the same variable.</description>
  <example>Given two segments of lengths 2·x and 5·x, their total is (2 + 5)·x = 7·x.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the distributive property to factor out a common factor: a·x + a·y = a·(x + y). This is useful for simplifying or comparing expressions.</description>
  <example>For 4·m + 4·n, factor to get 4·(m + n), making it easier to see the combined length or quantity.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check units and consistency: ensure all terms represent the same unit before summing. Mixing units (e.g., hours vs. minutes) leads to errors.</description>
  <example>If one segment is in hours and another in minutes, convert both to the same unit (e.g., minutes) before adding.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>After forming an expression, verify by plugging in a simple test value for the variable. This helps catch algebraic mistakes.</description>
  <example>For T = 2·x + 3·x, test x = 1: T = 2·1 + 3·1 = 5, which matches (2 + 3)·1 = 5, confirming correctness.</example>
</note1>

<note1>
  <description>Convert units by multiplying by the appropriate conversion factor. For example, to convert a quantity from one unit to another, multiply by the ratio of the target unit to the source unit.</description>
  <example>Convert 50 items into dozens by multiplying by 1 dozen/12 items, yielding (50 items)×(1 dozen/12 items)=4.1667 dozen.</example>
</note1>
 <note2>
  <description>Use the distributive property to simplify multiplication over addition. When a quantity is expressed as a sum, distribute the multiplier across each term before combining.</description>
  <example>Compute 7×(3+4) by distributing: 7×3 + 7×4 = 21 + 28 = 49.</example>
</note1>
 <note3>
  <description>Break a multi-step problem into sequential steps and solve each step in order. This ensures clarity and reduces errors in complex calculations.</description>
  <example>To find total eggs in 12 weeks, first compute daily eggs (3 eggs/day), then weekly eggs (3×7), and finally total eggs (weekly eggs×12).</example>
</note1>
 <note4>
  <description>Check for integer or fractional results when dealing with discrete items. If a result is not an integer, interpret it as a fraction of a unit or round as appropriate.</description>
  <example>After finding 4.1667 dozen, recognize that 0.1667 dozen equals 2 eggs, so the total is 4 dozen and 2 extra eggs.</example>
</note1>
 <note5>
  <description>Verify your answer by reversing the steps or using an alternative method. This helps catch arithmetic or unit conversion mistakes.</description>
  <example>After computing 4.1667 dozen, convert back: 4.1667×12 items = 50 items, then divide by 3 items/egg to get 16.6667 eggs, confirming the original daily count.</example>
</note1>

<note1>
  <description>Compute the volume of a rectangular prism by multiplying its three dimensions: V = length × width × height. This applies to any box-shaped container.</description>
  <example>For a box with dimensions 5 units × 3 units × 2 units, the volume is 5 × 3 × 2 = 30 cubic units.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Account for packing efficiency by multiplying the container’s volume by the packing density (a decimal between 0 and 1). This gives the effective volume occupied by the objects.</description>
  <example>If a container has volume 30 cubic units and objects pack at 70% efficiency, the effective volume is 30 × 0.70 = 21 cubic units.</example>
</note1>
<note3>
  <description>Find the total number of objects by dividing the effective volume by the volume of one object: N = effective volume ÷ object volume. Ensure units match.</description>
  <example>With an effective volume of 21 cubic units and each object occupying 0.5 cubic units, the total count is 21 ÷ 0.5 = 42 objects.</example>
</note1>
<note4>
  <description>Extract a subset of objects by multiplying the total count by the desired fraction or percentage: subset = total × fraction. Use decimals for percentages.</description>
  <example>If 42 objects are total and 25% are of a certain type, the count is 42 × 0.25 = 10.5, which you would round or adjust as needed.</example>
</note1>
<note5>
  <description>Compute the absolute error between an estimate and the true value: error = |estimate − true|. This measures how far off the guess is.</description>
  <example>If the estimate is 10.5 and the true value is 12, the error is |10.5 − 12| = 1.5.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a fraction of a total quantity is taken, multiply the total by that fraction to find the part. This works because a fraction represents a proportional share of the whole.</description>
  <example>For a total of T items and a fraction f, the taken amount is T × f. For instance, if T = 100 and f = 1/4, then taken = 100 × 1/4 = 25.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Convert a worded fraction into a numerical ratio before multiplying. This ensures clarity and avoids misinterpretation of “of” as addition or subtraction.</description>
  <example>“Two-fifths of the items” becomes 2/5. If total items = 150, then 2/5 of 150 = (2/5) × 150 = 60.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the unitary method: find the value for one unit, then scale to the required number. This is useful when the total is large or when the fraction is complex.</description>
  <example>If one item costs C, then for N items the cost is N × C. For example, if one orange costs $2 and you have 30 oranges, total cost = 30 × 2 = $60.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check that the fraction and total are compatible (e.g., total divisible by denominator). If not, consider rounding or re-evaluating the problem setup to avoid fractional items.</description>
  <example>With total T = 120 and fraction 1/3, 120 ÷ 3 = 40 is an integer, so 1/3 of 120 = 40. If T = 121, 121 ÷ 3 is not an integer, so you must decide whether to round or adjust the fraction.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify by reversing the operation: multiply the computed part by the reciprocal of the fraction to see if you recover the original total.</description>
  <example>If you found 40 items as 1/3 of 120, check 40 × (3/1) = 120. If the result matches the original total, the calculation is correct.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert total items into total units by multiplying the number of items by the number of units per item. This gives a single total count for further calculations.</description>
  <example>For 40 boxes each containing 80 items, compute 40 × 80 = 3200 items in total.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Translate comparative statements into algebraic equations. Use variables for each quantity and express “more than” or “times as many” relationships as linear equations.</description>
  <example>If A eats 30 more than B, write A = B + 30. If C eats twice as many as B, write C = 2·B.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use substitution to solve a system of two linear equations in two variables. Express one variable in terms of another from one equation, then substitute into the second.</description>
  <example>Given A = B + 30 and C = 2·B, and knowing A = 100, substitute to get 100 = B + 30, so B = 70, then C = 2·70 = 140.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Verify the solution by substituting back into all original equations. This ensures consistency and catches arithmetic or sign errors.</description>
  <example>Check A = 100, B = 70, C = 140: 100 = 70 + 30 and 140 = 2·70 both hold, confirming correctness.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Compute the total of all quantities by summing the solved variables. This final step aggregates individual results into the overall total.</description>
  <example>With A = 100, B = 70, C = 140, the total is 100 + 70 + 140 = 310.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When multiple groups each perform the same task, multiply the number of groups by the task rate per group. This aggregates individual contributions into a total rate.</description>
  <example>Three friends each write 4 pages per hour. Total pages per hour = 3 × 4 = 12 pages.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Convert between units of time and work rate by using the reciprocal of the time per unit. If one unit takes t minutes, then the rate is 1/t units per minute.</description>
  <example>If it takes 10 minutes to write one page, then the writing rate is 1/10 pages per minute.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When two tasks occur simultaneously, add their rates to get the combined rate. This applies to writing and reading responses that happen at the same time.</description>
  <example>Writing at 1/10 pages/min and reading at 1/15 pages/min together yield (1/10 + 1/15) = 1/6 pages per minute.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Compute total work by multiplying the combined rate by the time duration. This gives the total number of units completed in that period.</description>
  <example>At a combined rate of 1/6 pages/min for 60 minutes, total pages = (1/6) × 60 = 10 pages.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Convert total time from minutes to hours by dividing by 60. This is essential when the final answer must be in hours.</description>
  <example>If total writing time is 180 minutes, then hours = 180 ÷ 60 = 3 hours.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a total quantity is split into two equal parts, each part is the total divided by 2. This applies whenever a problem states “half of” or “equal shares.”</description>
  <example>For a total of T items, the first half is T/2 and the second half is also T/2. For instance, if T=100, each half is 50.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>To find a fraction of a quantity, multiply the total by that fraction. Use this for any “one-third,” “one-quarter,” or other fractional parts.</description>
  <example>Given a total of T and a fraction f, the portion is f·T. For example, one-third of T=100 is (1/3)·100≈33.33.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>When a subset of a subset is asked for, multiply the two fractions. If the first fraction is f₁ and the second is f₂, the result is f₁·f₂·T.</description>
  <example>For a total T, half of it is f₁=1/2, and half of that is f₂=1/2, so the final portion is (1/2)·(1/2)·T = T/4.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check that the fractions you multiply are of the same total. Mixing different totals leads to incorrect results.</description>
  <example>If you have T₁ items and then take half of T₁, you cannot then take half of T₂ (a different total) without re-evaluating the base.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>After computing a fractional portion, verify by adding back the remainder to ensure it sums to the original total. This catches arithmetic or logical errors.</description>
  <example>If you find P items in one part, check that the remaining T–P items in the other part also sum to T. For T=100 and P=25, the other part is 75, and 25+75=100.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Translate comparative statements into algebraic equations by assigning a variable to one quantity and expressing others in terms of it. For example, if A is k times B, write A = k·B. If B is d less than C, write B = C – d. This creates a system of equations.</description>
  <example>Suppose X is twice Y, and Y is 5 more than Z. Assign Z = z, then Y = z + 5, and X = 2·(z + 5). These equations capture the relationships.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the total-sum condition to form a single equation. If the sum of all variables equals S, write Var₁ + Var₂ + … + Varₙ = S. This equation, combined with the comparative equations, yields a solvable system.</description>
  <example>With X = 2(z + 5), Y = z + 5, Z = z, and X + Y + Z = 370, substitute to get 2(z + 5) + (z + 5) + z = 370. This single equation in z can be solved.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Combine like terms and isolate the variable by standard algebraic manipulation. Collect all terms involving the variable on one side and constants on the other, then divide by the coefficient.</description>
  <example>From 2(z + 5) + (z + 5) + z = 370, expand to 2z + 10 + z + 5 + z = 370, combine to 4z + 15 = 370, subtract 15 to get 4z = 355, then divide by 4 to find z = 355/4.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for consistency by substituting the found value back into all original equations. Ensure each comparative and sum condition holds true, and verify no extraneous solutions were introduced.</description>
  <example>After finding z = 355/4, compute Y = z + 5 = 355/4 + 5 = 375/4, and X = 2·Y = 750/4. Then X + Y + Z = 750/4 + 375/4 + 355/4 = 1480/4 = 370, confirming consistency.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Be cautious of integer constraints and unit consistency. If the problem requires integer lengths, ensure the solution yields whole numbers; otherwise, re-examine the setup for misinterpretation.</description>
  <example>If the final z = 355/4 is not an integer, revisit the relationships or check if the total sum was misstated. Only proceed if the solution fits the required integer or unit context.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute the total by multiplying each category’s count by its value and summing. This applies whenever you have grouped data with different values.</description>
  <example>For items A with value v₁ and count n₁, and items B with value v₂ and count n₂, total = n₁·v₁ + n₂·v₂.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a category’s value is a fraction of another, express it as a ratio or fraction of the reference value. This avoids recomputing the base value from scratch.</description>
  <example>If category C has half the value of category B, then C’s value = (1/2)·v₂.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the weighted average formula: average = (Σ (countᵢ·valueᵢ)) / (Σ countᵢ). This generalizes to any number of categories.</description>
  <example>With counts n₁, n₂, n₃ and values v₁, v₂, v₃, average = (n₁v₁ + n₂v₂ + n₃v₃) / (n₁ + n₂ + n₃).</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for consistency: ensure all values and counts are in the same units and that no category is omitted. This prevents arithmetic errors.</description>
  <example>Before summing, verify that each count corresponds to exactly one value and that no group is double-counted.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Perform a sanity check by comparing the computed average to the extremes of the data. If the average is too far from the smallest or largest value, re-examine your calculations.</description>
  <example>If the smallest value is v_min and the largest is v_max, the average should lie between v_min and v_max; otherwise, there is likely a mistake.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert total weight to total count by multiplying weight by density: total_count = total_weight × density. This works whenever you know how many units fit in a given weight.</description>
  <example>Suppose you have W units of material per ounce and you have T ounces. Then total units = T × W. For instance, if W=5 units/ounce and T=8 ounces, total units = 8 × 5 = 40 units.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute the number of containers by dividing total count by container capacity: containers = total_count ÷ capacity. This gives the raw count before accounting for partial containers.</description>
  <example>If you have 40 units and each container holds C units, then raw containers = 40 ÷ C. For example, if C=6, raw containers = 40 ÷ 6 ≈ 6.67.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use integer division to count full containers: full_containers = ⌊total_count ÷ capacity⌋. This ensures you only count complete containers.</description>
  <example>With 40 units and capacity 6, full_containers = ⌊40 ÷ 6⌋ = 6. You cannot fill a seventh container completely.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check leftover units: remainder = total_count mod capacity. This tells you how many units remain after packing full containers.</description>
  <example>Continuing the example, remainder = 40 mod 6 = 4. So 4 units are left unpacked.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Handle partial containers by deciding whether to include them. If you need at least one container for leftovers, add one more container: containers = full_containers + (1 if remainder > 0 else 0).</description>
  <example>With full_containers = 6 and remainder = 4, you would add one more container, giving total containers = 6 + 1 = 7.</example>
</note5>

<note1>
  <description>Compute the arithmetic mean by summing all values and dividing by the count. This gives the average of a set of numbers.</description>
  <example>For values a, b, c, d, e, the mean is (a + b + c + d + e) / 5.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Use the weighted average formula when each value has a different weight. The weighted mean is Σ (value_i × weight_i) / Σ weight_i.</description>
  <example>With values a, b, c and weights w₁, w₂, w₃, the weighted mean is (a·w₁ + b·w₂ + c·w₃) / (w₁ + w₂ + w₃).</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Apply the identity that adding a constant to each value increases the mean by that constant. This simplifies comparisons or adjustments.</description>
  <example>If each of n values is increased by k, the new mean is old_mean + k.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>Use the deviation identity: the sum of deviations from the mean is zero. This helps verify calculations and understand how far each value lies from the average.</description>
  <example>For values a, b, c, d, e with mean m, then (a–m) + (b–m) + (c–m) + (d–m) + (e–m) = 0.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>Check for outliers or extreme values that can skew the mean. Consider using median or trimmed mean if a few values are unusually high or low.</description>
  <example>If one value is much larger than the others, the mean may not represent the central tendency well; compare with the median instead.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the multiplication principle: for each category, multiply the count by the number of legs per animal. This works because each animal contributes a fixed number of legs independently.</description>
  <example>For 3 dogs with 4 legs each, compute 3 × 4 = 12 legs. For 2 cats with 4 legs each, compute 2 × 4 = 8 legs.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Sum the results of each category’s multiplication. This aggregates the total legs across all types of animals.</description>
  <example>After finding 12 legs from dogs and 8 legs from cats, add them: 12 + 8 = 20 legs.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the distributive property: (a + b + c) × k = a·k + b·k + c·k. This simplifies multi-category calculations by factoring out the common leg count.</description>
  <example>For 3 dogs, 2 cats, and 1 bird (4 legs each), compute (3 + 2 + 1) × 4 = 6 × 4 = 24 legs.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check for consistency by verifying that each category’s count and leg count match known values. This guards against miscounting or misreading the problem.</description>
  <example>Ensure you used 4 legs for dogs and cats, not 2 or 6, and that you counted 3 dogs and 2 cats correctly before multiplying.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use a unit conversion perspective: legs = (number of animals) × (legs per animal). This viewpoint helps when dealing with different units or when extending to other attributes.</description>
  <example>View legs as “animal-leg units.” For 3 dogs, you have 3 animal-leg units × 4 legs per unit = 12 legs.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert percentage to decimal by dividing by 100. This lets you multiply directly with the original amount.</description>
  <example>For a 20% discount, compute 20/100 = 0.20. Then multiply the original price by 0.20 to find the discount amount.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute the discount amount by multiplying the original price by the decimal form of the percentage. This gives the absolute reduction.</description>
  <example>With a 15% discount on an item priced at $200, calculate 0.15 × 200 = $30, which is the discount amount.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Find the final price by subtracting the discount amount from the original price. This yields the net cost after the reduction.</description>
  <example>After finding a $30 discount on a $200 item, subtract: 200 – 30 = $170, giving the final price.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Alternatively, compute the final price directly by multiplying the original price by (1 – decimal percentage). This combines both steps into one.</description>
  <example>For a 15% discount on $200, calculate 200 × (1 – 0.15) = 200 × 0.85 = $170.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check that the final price is less than or equal to the original price. This ensures the discount was applied correctly.</description>
  <example>If you get a final price of $210 after a 15% discount on $200, recompute to catch an error, since $210 is higher than $200.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>When comparing two quantities, subtract the smaller from the larger to find the difference. This works for any two values, regardless of context.</description>
  <example>Quantity A = 100, Quantity B = 75. The difference is 100 – 75 = 25.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>To find a fraction of a total, multiply the total by the fraction. This applies whenever you need a part of a whole.</description>
  <example>Total = 100, fraction = 3/4. The part is 100 × (3/4) = 75.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Always simplify fractions before performing arithmetic to reduce errors and make calculations easier. Simplification involves dividing numerator and denominator by their greatest common divisor.</description>
  <example>Fraction = 6/8. Divide both by 2 to get 3/4, then compute 100 × (3/4) = 75.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Check your result by reversing the operation: if you found a part, divide that part by the fraction to see if you recover the original total. This ensures consistency.</description>
  <example>Part = 75, fraction = 3/4. Compute 75 ÷ (3/4) = 75 × (4/3) = 100, matching the original total.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>When the question asks “how much greater,” ensure you subtract in the correct order: larger – smaller. Reversing the order gives the wrong sign or magnitude.</description>
  <example>Quantity A = 100, Quantity B = 75. The correct difference is 100 – 75 = 25, not 75 – 100 = –25.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>When one quantity is described as “k more than” another, represent it as the base value plus k. This linear relationship simplifies comparisons and calculations.</description>
  <example>Suppose item A costs x and item B costs k more than A. Then B = x + k. For instance, if A = 10 and k = 3, B = 13.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>For a discount of p% off a price P, compute the sale price as P × (1 – p/100). This formula applies to any percentage off.</description>
  <example>If an item originally costs P = 50 and is 25% off, the sale price is 50 × (1 – 0.25) = 37.5.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When multiple discounts or coupons apply, apply them sequentially: subtract each discount or coupon amount from the current total. This ensures correct cumulative savings.</description>
  <example>Start with total T = 100. Apply a $10 coupon (T = 90), then a 10% discount (T = 90 × 0.9 = 81). Final total = 81.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Use the distributive property to combine like terms: a(b + c) = ab + ac. This helps simplify expressions before final computation.</description>
  <example>Given 2 × (x + 5), distribute to get 2x + 10. If x = 3, then 2x + 10 = 6 + 10 = 16.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify by re-adding all individual costs and discounts to ensure no step was omitted or miscalculated. This check catches arithmetic or logical errors.</description>
  <example>After computing subtotal S = 80 and applying a $5 coupon, re-add: 80 – 5 = 75. Confirm this matches the final total.</example>
Define variables for each person’s age (e.g., S for Steve, W for wife, C for son, X for son’s wife). Use these variables consistently throughout the problem.

<note1>
  <description>Convert percentages to decimals by dividing by 100. This lets you multiply directly with quantities. For example, 0.3% becomes 0.003, and 30% becomes 0.30.</description>
  <example>Find 15% of 200. Convert 15% to 0.15, then compute 0.15 × 200 = 30.</example>
</note1>
  <note2>
  <description>Use the distributive property to simplify expressions like a × (b + c). Compute a × b and a × c separately, then add. This avoids nested parentheses and reduces errors.</description>
  <example>Calculate 7 × (5 + 3). First find 7 × 5 = 35 and 7 × 3 = 21, then add to get 56.</example>
</note2>
  <note3>
  <description>When combining items in groups, multiply the number of groups by the number of items per group. This gives the total count before further operations.</description>
  <example>If you have 4 boxes and each box contains 12 pencils, total pencils = 4 × 12 = 48.</example>
</note3>
  <note4>
  <description>Apply the unitary method: find the value of one unit, then multiply by the total number of units. This is useful for pricing, rates, and scaling.</description>
  <example>If one widget costs $2.50, then 10 widgets cost 10 × $2.50 = $25.00.</example>
</note4>
  <note5>
  <description>Always check units and consistency: ensure all quantities are in the same unit before adding or multiplying. Mismatched units lead to incorrect results.</description>
  <example>Don’t add 5 meters and 5 kilograms; convert both to the same unit (e.g., 5 m = 500 cm, 5 kg = 5000 g) before combining if needed.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>Use the unit-price method: divide the total cost by the quantity to find the cost per unit, then multiply by the desired quantity. This works for any item with a fixed price per unit.</description>
  <example>For a product priced at P per unit, the cost for Q units is (P × Q). If you need R units, compute (P × R) to get the total cost.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Apply percentage discounts by converting the discount rate to a decimal and multiplying by the original price. The sale price equals original price minus (discount rate × original price).</description>
  <example>For an item priced at P with a 25% discount, compute 0.25 × P to get the discount amount, then subtract from P to get the sale price: P − (0.25 × P).</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the “buy one, get one free” or “buy one, get one at a reduced price” rule by treating each pair as a single unit at the effective price. Multiply the effective price by the number of pairs to get the total cost.</description>
  <example>If you get one item at full price P and one at half price 0.5P, each pair costs P + 0.5P = 1.5P. For N pairs, total cost is N × 1.5P.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Sum all individual costs to find the total expenditure. This additive approach works for any combination of items with different prices.</description>
  <example>For items costing C₁, C₂, C₃, …, the total cost is C₁ + C₂ + C₃ + … . Add each cost to get the overall expense.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Compute remaining funds by subtracting total expenditure from the initial amount. This simple subtraction gives the leftover money.</description>
  <example>If you start with A and spend T, then the remaining amount is A − T. This applies to any scenario where you know the initial and total costs.</example>
</note1>

30 days
<note1>
  <description>Convert a fraction of a period into total units by multiplying the fraction by the full period. This works whenever you need a portion of a time span or quantity.</description>
  <example>For a 30-day month, one-fifth of the month is 30 × (1/5) = 6 days.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Use the unit-rate method: if an action occurs at a constant rate, multiply the rate by the total time. This applies to any scenario with a fixed frequency.</description>
  <example>If Tyrion changes a mask 2 times per outing and goes out 3 times a day, then per day he uses 2 × 3 = 6 masks.</example>
</note3>
<note4>
  <description>Combine multiple rates by summing them. When several independent processes contribute to a total, add their rates to get the overall rate.</description>
  <example>With 2 mask-changes per outing and 3 outings per day, the combined daily rate is 2 + 3 = 5 events per day.</example>
</note5>
<note6>
  <description>Apply the distributive property to simplify expressions: a × (b + c) = a·b + a·c. This helps break down complex multiplications into simpler parts.</description>
  <example>For 6 days and 5 events per day, compute 6 × 5 by thinking 6 × (2 + 3) = 6×2 + 6×3 = 12 + 18 = 30.</example>
</note6>

<note1>
  <description>When a quantity grows by a constant factor each period, model it as a geometric sequence: aₙ = a₁·rⁿ⁻¹. Use this when each term is r times the previous term.</description>
  <example>Suppose a plant produces 10 fruits in year 1 and doubles each year. Then in year 4 it produces 10·2³ = 80 fruits.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>When a quantity is described as a multiple of an initial amount, introduce a variable for the initial value and express later values as that variable times a factor. This keeps the solution general.</description>
  <example>Let the initial production be x. If the second year’s production is 3x, then x = 50 (from the problem) gives the second year’s production as 3·50 = 150.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>Translate “less than” or “more than” statements into algebraic equations: if A is k less than B, write A = B – k; if A is k more than B, write A = B + k. This handles relative comparisons.</description>
  <example>If a 7-year-old tree produces 7.5 times the initial amount and a 10-year-old produces 200 fruits less, set 7.5x = (20-year-old production) – 200.</example>
</note4>
<note4>
  <description>When a term is zero or absent, include it in the sum with value zero. This ensures the total sum correctly accounts for all periods.</description>
  <example>If the 9th year has no production, include 0 in the sum of annual outputs to get the total over 10 years.</example>
</note5>
<note5>
  <description>Compute the total over a finite number of periods by summing the sequence: for a geometric sequence, use Sₙ = a₁·(rⁿ – 1)/(r – 1). For non-geometric, sum term by term.</description>
  <example>For a₁ = 50, r = 3 over 4 terms: S₄ = 50·(3⁴ – 1)/(3 – 1) = 50·(81 – 1)/2 = 2000.</example>
</note5>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a quantity increases by a percentage p, multiply the original amount by (1 + p/100). This converts a percentage increase into a direct multiplier.</description>
  <example>Original cost = C. If it increases by 20%, new cost = C × (1 + 20/100) = 1.20 × C.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When a quantity decreases by a percentage p, multiply the original amount by (1 – p/100). This converts a percentage decrease into a direct multiplier.</description>
  <example>Original cost = C. If it decreases by 15%, new cost = C × (1 – 15/100) = 0.85 × C.</example>
</note2>
3. <note3>
  <description>For a percentage change of p, the reciprocal (1/(1 + p/100)) or (1/(1 – p/100)) gives the inverse change. Use this to reverse a percentage increase or decrease.</description>
  <example>If an amount increased by 25% to become D, the original amount is D × (1/(1 + 25/100)) = D × 0.80.</example>
</note3>
4. <note4>
  <description>When two quantities are in a ratio a : b, the larger is (b/(a + b)) × total, and the smaller is (a/(a + b)) × total. This splits a total into proportional parts.</description>
  <example>Two parts in ratio 3 : 2 sum to T. The larger part = (3/(3 + 2)) × T = 0.60 × T, the smaller = 0.40 × T.</example>
</note4>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check that your result is consistent with the problem’s context. Verify units, sign, and magnitude to catch arithmetic or logical errors.</description>
  <example>If you compute a cost as negative, re-examine the percentage multiplier or sign convention. If the result is too large, re-check the ratio or percentage calculation.</example>
</note5>
first convert each time to hours by dividing by 60, then multiply by the number of days, and finally sum the results.

1. <note1>
  <description>When a fraction of a total is taken, multiply the fraction by the total to find the count. This works because “fraction of total” = (fraction) × (total).</description>
  <example>For a total of T items, taking p/q of them yields (p/q)·T items.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>When two fractions of the same total are added, convert them to a common denominator or add directly if they share the same denominator. The sum of fractions equals the sum of their numerators over the common denominator.</description>
  <example>Adding p/q of T and r/q of T gives (p + r)/q of T, so the total count is ((p + r)/q)·T.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>To find a multiple of a previous count, multiply the original count by the multiplier. This applies whenever a quantity is scaled by a factor k.</description>
  <example>If a count is C, then k times that count is k·C.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>When combining counts from different days or steps, sum all individual counts. This is the basic principle of additive aggregation in discrete problems.</description>
  <example>Given counts C₁, C₂, and C₃, the total is C₁ + C₂ + C₃.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always check that the final total does not exceed the original total or any given constraints. This ensures consistency and catches overcounting.</description>
  <example>If the sum of counts exceeds T, re-examine each step for arithmetic or logical errors.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>When a total quantity is split equally among n parts, each part receives the total divided by n. This applies to any equal distribution problem.</description>
  <example>Suppose 60 items are shared equally among 5 containers. Each container gets 60 ÷ 5 = 12 items.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Half of a quantity is found by multiplying the quantity by 1/2. This is a special case of fraction multiplication.</description>
  <example>Half of 20 units is 20 × 1/2 = 10 units.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>When two quantities are combined, add them to get the new total. Then apply any further distribution or calculation to that sum.</description>
  <example>Combining 15 units and 25 units yields 40 units. If you then split these 40 units into 4 groups, each group has 40 ÷ 4 = 10 units.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>After distributing items into multiple groups, to find the total in a subset of groups, multiply the per-group count by the number of groups in the subset.</description>
  <example>If each of 10 boxes holds 7 items, then 4 boxes hold 4 × 7 = 28 items.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Always verify your result by reversing the steps: reconstruct the original quantities from your final answer to ensure consistency.</description>
  <example>If you conclude 28 items are in 4 boxes, check by dividing 28 by 4 to see if you recover 7 items per box, matching the initial distribution.</example>
</note1>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute total output by multiplying rate (units per time) by total time (hours or days). This gives the number of items produced over the given period.</description>
  <example>Machine A produces 10 units/hour and runs for 8 hours. Total output = 10 units/hour × 8 hours = 80 units.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Convert daily or monthly time into hours by multiplying by the number of hours per day and days per month. This ensures all time units are consistent before computing output.</description>
  <example>Machine B runs 24 hours/day for 30 days. Total hours = 24 hours/day × 30 days = 720 hours.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Calculate revenue by multiplying total output by unit price. This gives the total income generated from selling all items.</description>
  <example>Each item sells for $5 and 80 items are produced. Revenue = 80 items × $5/item = $400.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Find the difference in revenue between two machines by subtracting the smaller revenue from the larger. This quantifies how much more one machine earns than the other.</description>
  <example>Machine A earns $400 and Machine B earns $300. Difference = $400 – $300 = $100.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use unitary method to find per-hour or per-day revenue: divide total revenue by total hours or days. This helps compare machines with different run times.</description>
  <example>Machine A earns $400 in 8 hours. Per-hour revenue = $400 ÷ 8 hours = $50/hour.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert all fractional and decimal quantities to a common form (fractions or decimals) before combining. This ensures consistency and avoids arithmetic errors.</description>
  <example>Given “1/8” and “0.125,” recognize that 0.125 = 1/8, so both are expressed as 1/8. Then you can add them directly as fractions.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Use the distributive property to handle “more than” phrases: if A eats x and B eats x + y, then B’s share = x + y. This clarifies relationships between quantities.</description>
  <example>“Sister ate 0.125 more than Doxa” means sister’s share = Doxa’s share + 0.125. If Doxa’s share is 1/8, then sister’s share = 1/8 + 0.125.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>Sum all individual shares by adding their common form. For fractions, find a common denominator; for decimals, align decimal points.</description>
  <example>Adding 1/8, 1/8, and 1/8 gives 3/8. Alternatively, adding 0.125, 0.125, and 0.125 gives 0.375, which equals 3/8.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Verify the total does not exceed the whole (1 or 100%). If it does, re-examine each conversion or addition step for mistakes.</description>
  <example>If you get 1.25 (125%) of the apple, check that you correctly converted and added all shares. A total over 1 indicates an error.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>When the problem asks for a count of pieces, multiply the total fraction by the total number of pieces. This scales the fractional result to the actual count.</description>
  <example>If the total eaten is 3/8 of the apple and there are 8 slices, then slices eaten = (3/8) × 8 = 3 slices.</example>

Define variables for each cooking time (e.g. r, p, b). Write one equation for each given time relation (e.g. p = r + 0.33, b = 0.5·(p + r)). Solve the system of linear equations to find p and b. Compute the total time as r + p + b.

1. <note1>
  <description>Convert percentages to decimals by dividing by 100, then multiply by the base quantity to find a percentage of that quantity. This works because “percent” means “per hundred.”</description>
  <example>Find 25% of 80. Convert 25% to 0.25, then compute 0.25 × 80 = 20.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Compute a percentage decrease by multiplying the original amount by (1 – p/100), where p is the percentage. This gives the reduced value directly.</description>
  <example>Original amount is 120, decrease by 15%. Compute 120 × (1 – 0.15) = 120 × 0.85 = 102.</example>
</note3>
3. <note3>
  <description>When one quantity is a multiple of another, multiply the base quantity by the factor. This scales the base to the desired multiple.</description>
  <example>If A = 50 and B is 3 times A, then B = 3 × 50 = 150.</example>
</note4>
4. <note4>
  <description>Always check that all computed values are nonnegative and make sense in context. Negative or zero results may indicate an error in setup or interpretation.</description>
  <example>After finding a decrease, ensure the result is ≥ 0. If you get –10 from a decrease, recheck the percentage or base value.</example>
</note5>
5. <note5>
  <description>Use unit consistency: ensure all quantities are in the same units before combining or comparing. Mixing units (e.g., hours vs. minutes) leads to incorrect results.</description>
  <example>If one rate is in “per hour” and another in “per minute,” convert one to match the other before adding or comparing.</example>

1. <note1>
  <description>Compute total cost by multiplying unit price by quantity. This applies whenever you know the price per item and the number of items purchased.</description>
  <example>For n items at price p each, total cost = n × p. For instance, if you buy 5 widgets at $20 each, total cost = 5 × 20 = $100.</example>
</note1>
2. <note2>
  <description>Find total revenue from individual high-value items by multiplying each item’s value by its count. Sum these products to get the total revenue from those items.</description>
  <example>If you have 2 special cards worth $1000 each and 3 cards worth $500 each, total revenue = 2 × 1000 + 3 × 500 = $2000 + $1500 = $3500.</example>
</note1>
3. <note3>
  <description>Use the average formula to find total value of a group: total = average × count. This is useful when you know the average value of a batch of items and the number of items.</description>
  <example>For 10 cards with an average value of $75, total value = 10 × 75 = $750.</example>
</note1>
4. <note4>
  <description>Compute profit by subtracting total cost from total revenue. Ensure both totals are in the same currency before subtracting.</description>
  <example>If total cost is $1200 and total revenue is $1500, profit = 1500 − 1200 = $300.</example>
</note1>
5. <note5>
  <description>Check for unit consistency and avoid mixing different units (e.g., dollars vs. cents). Always convert all values to the same unit before performing arithmetic.</description>
  <example>If one cost is given in dollars and another in cents, convert cents to dollars (e.g., 50 cents = $0.50) before adding or subtracting.</example>
</note1>

<note1>
  <description>When a journey is split into segments with different speeds, compute each segment’s time as distance divided by speed. This works because time = distance/speed for uniform motion.</description>
  <example>For a 10 km trip split into 4 km at 5 km/h and 6 km at 3 km/h, times are 4/5=0.8 h and 6/3=2 h.</example>
</note1>
<note2>
  <description>Use the average speed formula v_avg = total distance / total time when speeds vary. This gives the overall rate for the entire journey.</description>
  <example>With 10 km at 5 km/h and 10 km at 3 km/h, total time is 2+3.33=5.33 h, so v_avg = 20/5.33 ≈ 3.75 km/h.</example>
</note2>
<note3>
  <description>When equal distances are traveled at two speeds v₁ and v₂, the average speed is 2v₁v₂/(v₁+v₂). This is a special case of the harmonic mean for two rates.</description>
  <example>Equal 5 km at 10 km/h and 15 km/h gives v_avg = 2·10·15/(10+15) = 300/25 = 12 km/h.</example>
</note4>
<note5>
  <description>Always check units and consistency: distances and speeds must share the same units before dividing. Convert if necessary to avoid errors.</description>
  <example>If speed is given in m/s and distance in km, convert distance to meters or speed to km/h before computing time.</example>
</note6>
